mentions.context: Krippendorf's alpha (computed using the simpledorff python library) was 0.41.
5 Due to space constraints, we do not show results obtained for AlBERT large-v2 but they are consistent with the description provided in the previous paragraph.
However, it is not consistent with the finding of bias higher in AlBERT compared to RoBERTa.
We obtain a value of 60.4, which is consistent with the finding of bias for AlBERT (the value is still well over 50).
However, we can notice that the metric score reported by (Nangia et al., 2020) for AlBERT xxlarge-v2 was higher in value (67.0) compared to our experiment with AlBERT large-v2.
However, it is not consistent with the finding of bias higher in AlBERT compared to RoBERTa.

The results were reproduced at the dimension of value for BERT and main finding for RoBERTa (Liu et al., 2019) and AlBERT (Lan et al., 2020) 3 , which do exhibit high bias scores in our 3 The metric scores obtained in our reproduction were 60.5 for BERT, 65.4 for RoBERTa and 60.5 for AlBERT.
These differences can be explained by the use of upgraded versions of the torch and transformers packages and AlBERT model.
